W4393303675_s0550.English Original: Does the setting convey status, privilege, or other meaning?

W4393303675_s0551.English Original: The open air covered balcony and curtains on the balcony hints at a level of status and privilege reserved for the upper classes.

W4393303675_s0552.English Original: Additionally, the beautiful view was not one frequently seen in urban settings and would be a privileged view/ environment for wealthy nobles with multistory fortresses or castles in the countryside.

W4393303675_s0553.English Original: Are the people in the artwork clothed?

W4393303675_s0554.English Original: If not, are the naked bodies ornamented or fashioned in some way?

W4393303675_s0556.English Original: How are the people oriented (front facing, threequarter view, profile, or back facing)?

W4393303675_s0558.English Original: a. Caterina is positioned in a 3/4th angle with her back shoulder away from the viewer.

W4393303675_s0559.English Original: She has her head positioned the same way with her eyes tilted in the opposite way.

W4393303675_s0560.English Original: This orientation, a common one in many portraits of the period, can be a hint at the more natural setting in which she is depicted.

W4393303675_s0561.English Original: Instead of having some form of formal aristocratic portrait, the painting appears to capture Caterina in an almost candid scene.

W4393303675_s0562.English Original: What is the gender of each person in the image?

W4393303675_s0563.English Original: Has the artist emphasized gender or obscured it?

W4393303675_s0564.English Original: a. Caterina is a woman in which her gender is played up in several ways in this portrait.

W4393303675_s0565.English Original: Her hair hangs in a way that frames her face in which she can said to have warm honey colored eyes.

W4393303675_s0566.English Original: Furthermore, the stomacher insert she wears and the lacing of her gown across her bosom draws attention to this feminine organ.

W4393303675_s0567.English Original: Additionally, the fact that Caterina is organizing the flowers (jasmine according to one of the titles) in the bowl in front of her, a typically feminine domestic activity of noblewomen, adds to her feminine and domestic persona in the painting.

W4393303675_s0568.English Original: Consider the posture of the sitter(s).

W4393303675_s0569.English Original: Are they seated, standing, or reclining?

W4393303675_s0570.English Original: Are parts of the body not visible in the image?

W4393303675_s0571.English Original: Is their posture rigid or relaxed?

W4393303675_s0572.English Original: Is posture indicative of state of mind and/or training of the body?

W4393303675_s0573.English Original: a. Caterina is sitting in a position that is slightly slouched, but this could be due to her being "captured" in movement as she arranges the flowers in the bowl.

W4393303675_s0574.English Original: She is seated at a table so the bottom half of her gown is not visible.

W4393303675_s0575.English Original: Caterina was raised at the Sforza Milanese court as the illegitimate daughter of the Galeazza and her mother…… Landriani, as such she was given a formal education befitting a noblewoman in which the pose depicted in this painting would be expected of her ( ).

W4393303675_s0576.English Original: Her sloped shoulders lack a bit of realism based on the angle of the slope, but this posture (less exaggerated) could be achieved to some extent due to the dress hanging close off the shoulders.

W4393303675_s0577.English Original: Are other objects or animals included in the image to depict activities, interest, or status,…?

W4393303675_s0578.English Original: How does the sitter engage with these objects?

W4393303675_s0579.English Original: a. Caterina is clearly arranging flowers in the painting.

W4393303675_s0580.English Original: Such as pastime was akin to embroidery and other feminine activities for noblewomen of the time.

W4393303675_s0581.English Original: Caterina's fingers are depicted in mid motion as she plucks one flower from the bowl with one hand and seeks a place to replace it with the other hand.

W4393303675_s0582.English Original: Describe the main elements of clothing for each person in the image in detail, noting the garment category and how it is worn.

W4393303675_s0583.English Original: Also note whether any outdoor clothing.

W4393303675_s0584.English Original: a. Caterina wear a simple blue gown with and camicia underneath, and a green stomacher.

W4393303675_s0585.English Original: The camicia is visible in the distinct slashings on the sleeves of her gown that are held together with lacing.

W4393303675_s0586.English Original:
The camicia bursting from the sleeve slashing greats a puffed and voluminous decorative effect to the otherwise

unadorned sleeves.

W4393303675_s0587.English Original: The camicia is also visible peaking out of her neckline.

W4393303675_s0588.English Original: She also wears a red belt (girdle) tied at the center of her waist.

W4393303675_s0589.English Original: Can the type of textiles be determined?

W4393303675_s0590.English Original: Does the artist attempt to convey the nature of the textile,…?

W4393303675_s0591.English Original: Note the colors and dominant patterns in the textiles used for the clothing.

W4393303675_s0592.English Original: The type of textiles present in the painting can not be accurately determined.

W4393303675_s0593.English Original: However, the camicia can be approximated be made of linen as this was a common material for camicia during the period.

W4393303675_s0594.English Original: The outer dress is blue, the camicia is white, the stomacher is green with a black band at the top.

W4393303675_s0595.English Original: Is the clothing embellished in any way with fur, lace, jewels, embroidery, braid, or beading?

W4393303675_s0596.English Original: The clothing Caterina wears is only embellished with the red ties/ lacing.

W4393303675_s0597.English Original: Is any element of dress exaggerated?

W4393303675_s0598.English Original: The shape the gown makes around the stomacher is a bit exaggerated as the fabric lacks any wrinkles/ puckering, which would occur as stretch fabrics did not exist yet.

W4393303675_s0599.English Original: Describe the accessories of each person…Note how they are worn, carried, or placed in the image.

W4393303675_s0600.English Original: The bowl of flowers can be perceived to be an accessory.

W4393303675_s0601.English Original: However, it is slightly odd that Caterina is wearing no jewelry (no necklace, rings, hair pins, etc).

W4393303675_s0602.English Original: Are there visible signifiers of rank or status such as jewelry, metals, swords, or armor?

W4393303675_s0603.English Original: There are no signifiers such as the ones listed above.

W4393303675_s0604.English Original: However, the jasmine flowers in the bowl may have meaning as according to one title of the painting Caterina was known as the Lady of Jasmine.

W4393303675_s0605.English Original: Caterina was known during her time for her skill in alchemy, and jasmine is know for its various healing properties (Lifson, 2017).

W4393303675_s0606.English Original: Does the clothing serve as an occupational uniform or marker of identity?

W4393303675_s0607.English Original: The lack of elaborateness and lack of jewels in this portrait is ODD.

W4393303675_s0608.English Original: Describe the hairstyle and makeup of each person.

W4393303675_s0609.English Original: a. Caterina is depicted with a little bit of pink blush on her cheeks.

W4393303675_s0610.English Original: Her hair is pulled back in a bun with sections parted off and hanging curled and loose towards the front of her head.

W4393303675_s0611.English Original: Is this a realistic or abstracted image?

W4393303675_s0613.English Original: Are any parts of the image unfinished or indistinguishable?

W4393303675_s0614.English Original: There does not appear to be any unfinished or indistinguishable elements of this painting.

W4393303675_s0615.English Original: Does the artwork fit within a certain stylistic period in art history?

W4393303675_s0616.English Original: If so, is it consistent with the dominant characteristics of that style?

W4393303675_s0617.English Original: This painting fits within Italian High Renaissance painting techniques of the late 15th and early 16th century.

W4393303675_s0618.English Original: The attention to detail in the depiction of every strand of hair and the shading of the body and face is consistent with the time.

W4393303675_s0619.English Original: Furthermore, the shading and creases seen on the sleeves of her dress and the camicia are notable signs of the realism pursued by Renaissance painters such as Credi.

W4393303675_s0620.English Original: What is the sense of space in the work?

W4393303675_s0623.English Original: Is the sense of space literal or indeterminate?

W4393303675_s0624.English Original: The artist has a good grasp on defining space.

W4393303675_s0625.English Original: There is a clear foreground (the red covered table, her arm, and the bowl of flowers), a mid ground (extends from Caterina to the balcony ledge), and background (the entire landscape beyond the balcony setting).

W4393303675_s0626.English Original: The foreground and mid ground are tied together as Caterina interacts with each of these spaces.

W4393303675_s0627.English Original: However, the background exists as its own entity almost like a picture window.

W4393303675_s0628.English Original: Each of these spaces is intentional and literal, most likely representing real physical spaces, regardless of if these spaces were present when Credi was painting Caterina.

W4393303675_s0629.English Original: Has perspective been distorted or altered for specific effect?

W4393303675_s0630.English Original: The perspective is distorted in several places.

W4393303675_s0632.English Original: Her shoulders are sloped at an angle far too steep for a real human, possibly in an effort to foreground her shoulder that is facing towards the viewer.

W4393303675_s0633.English Original: Additionally the foliage on the trees in the background is far too detailed for how far away it would have been in real life, this can also be said for the highly in focus and detailed Rocca Sforzesca in the background.

W4393303675_s0634.English Original: What is the scale of the artwork relative to the human body and does this create the illusion of space or evoke a feeling or affect?

W4393303675_s0635.English Original: The artwork is relatively small, about 1/3 of human size.

W4393303675_s0636.English Original: In a way, it gives the feeling of a lot being "crammed" into such a small painting.

W4393303675_s0637.English Original: How was space used to contain the representation of the body?

W4393303675_s0638.English Original: Think of the lines within the artwork and how they echo or contain space around the bodies.

W4393303675_s0639.English Original: a. Caterina is framed in the center of the portrait however furniture and architecture within the painting aid in further bringing the eye back to her.

W4393303675_s0640.English Original: The pillar behind Caterina to the right of the painting provides a line between the background and the curtain that effectively "stops" the eye, while the red curtain perfectly frames Caterina's face and compliments her lighter shade of golden hair.

W4393303675_s0641.English Original: The line of the balcony ledge allows for the area behind Caterina's torso to remain plain, dark, and without further colored background elements to distract the eye.

W4393303675_s0642.English Original: This yet again draws the viewer's eyes to Caterina.

W4393303675_s0643.English Original: Does the use of color bring attention t certain forms, create movement, or generate a mood?

W4393303675_s0644.English Original: The use of red in numerous places aids in guiding the eye from Caterina's head (golden hair[according to Brewer, 1970], red curtain background), her torso (red lacings on her gown), to her hands on the table (red table).

W4393303675_s0645.English Original: Additionally the Rocca Sforzesca and the dirt road, in the background stands out in its grey and brown on the otherwise predominantly green and blue background landscape.

W4393303675_s0646.English Original: What does the artist emphasize visually?

W4393303675_s0648.English Original: a. Credi visually emphasized Caterina and the castle in the background.

W4393303675_s0649.English Original:
Theses two elements and their shared emphasis along with the color red are not by

accident or personal preference.

W4393303675_s0650.English Original: The abundance of red is a nod to the Catholic church and the pope who gifted Caterina and her then husband dominon over Imola and subsequently Forli.

W4393303675_s0651.English Original: The castle in the background could be Rocca Sforzesca, the castle Caterina would have resided in upon her arrival in Imola in the early 1480s.

W4393303675_s0652.English Original: How does the artist emphasize this aspect?

W4393303675_s0655.English Original: Is there an underlying rhythm, pattern, or geometric structure to the composition?

W4393303675_s0656.English Original: The color red present throughout the painting creates a rhythm and balance that aids in guiding the eye.

W4393303675_s0657.English Original: All of the key red elements in the painting are purposely centered within the composition, allowing for the sides (the space to the left of the red curtain and the space to the right of the red curtain and pillar) to offer brightness.

W4393303675_s0658.English Original: Unlike other Renaissance paintings and portraits, this painting seems to take on a rectangular geometric structure, utilizing the rectangle of the red curtain and the rectangle of the red covered table that sits in front of her, and the square/ rectangles that make up the space looking out into the background.

W4393303675_s0659.English Original: The only large distinct objects without four sides are Caterina and her gown and sleeves, along with the green bushes and tree tops in the background.

W4393303675_s0660.English Original: Is there a sense of balance or has the artist deliberately chosen to destabilize the composition?

W4393303675_s0661.English Original: While Caterina herself is centered the composition appears to be purposely off centered in a way.

W4393303675_s0662.English Original: The pillar on the right of the painting gives the viewer the illusion that Caterina is not centered in the composition, this paired with her ¾ pose and the partially drawn back red curtain all create this illusion of off balance that is aesthetically more pleasing than if Caterina were to be depicted in the center of the painting looking straight ahead.

W4393303675_s0663.English Original: Furthermore, the fact that the bowl of flowers is placed on the left side of the painting ties the composition back together as it creates a kind of diagonal motion (the background space on the right, then Caterina, then the bowl of flowers).

W4393303675_s0664.English Original: The bowl of flowers brings a color balance to the painting as the bowl and the flowers in it are of a similar color scheme as the natural background outside the balcony setting tying together the otherwise dark scheme within the balcony.

W4393303675_s0666.English Original: Do the elements appear integrated or separate from each other?

W4393303675_s0667.English Original: While at first glance the painting seems slightly separated, the spaces all interact and tie together utilizing color, line, and space.

W4393303675_s0668.English Original: Credi uses the concepts of foreground, middle ground, and background to separate te different elements of the painting, but successfully ties it back together in a way that strategically leads the viewer's eyes to what he wants to emphasize.

W4393303675_s0670.English Original: What do you think the artist is trying to express in this artwork?

W4393303675_s0672.English Original: a. I think Credi is trying to emphasize the success granted to a dutiful wife and loyal follower of the Pope and the Church.

W4393303675_s0673.English Original:
This is conveyed in the prominent

featuring of Caterina and her husband's assumed castle and principality in the background, along with her simple and humble style of dress, and the domestic feminine task she is conducting in the portrait.

W4393303675_s0674.English Original: Does the choice of medium impact the work in a material way?

W4393303675_s0675.English Original: Credi painted this portrait as it was tradition to paint portraits during this period.

W4393303675_s0676.English Original: Credi does not appear to use and difficult to obtain paint colors or incorporate gold leaf into the painting.

W4393303675_s0677.English Original: How has the artist used rest to define the profession, class, status, racial, or gender identity of the sitter?

W4393303675_s0678.English Original: As previously mentioned Caterina's leisurely activity of arranging flowers on her balcony that overlooks her castle is a clear definition of her status as an aristocrat.

W4393303675_s0679.English Original: A woman of a lower social class would not have time for such a leisurely activity nor have a view such as the one depicted.

W4393303675_s0680.English Original: If she were a man she would not be arranging flowers as this was considered a feminine pastime.

W4393303675_s0681.English Original: Is the dress of each sitter consistent with his or her gender, age, class, and occupation?

W4393303675_s0682.English Original: The dress of Caterina in this painting is not at all consistent with her class (but is consistent with her age and gender), as it is overall too simplistic to be worn by a granddaughter of the Duke of Milan and a member of the Sforza family.

W4393303675_s0683.English Original: She lacks the elaborate textiles and jewels noted to be worn by women in her family, including her halfsisters and stepmother ( ).

W4393303675_s0684.English Original: This is not to mention at the time this portrait was created she was the niece in law of Pope Sixtus IV (Pasolini, 1913).

W4393303675_s0685.English Original: Are the garments stylistically consistent with the period in which the artwork was created?

W4393303675_s0686.English Original: The gown's stomacher/modesty piece is more akin to the early 15th century/ late middle ages in style, yet the slashed sleeves is distinctly an Italian Renaissance style (Tortora & Marcketti, ).

W4393303675_s0687.English Original: The simpleness of the fabric used in her gown is also inconsistent for the period when taking into account her status and wealth.

W4393303675_s0688.English Original: Do the garments depicted have stylistic, religious, artistic, or iconic references?

W4393303675_s0689.English Original: The use of red lacings and her red belt can be in reference to red being a symbolic color of Christianity and the Catholic Church.

W4393303675_s0690.English Original: Her simple style could also play into religion as she could be aiming to depict herself in a humble and pious manner akin to the Virgin Mary, unadorned domesticity.

W4393303675_s0691.English Original: How does the clothing shape and fashion the body?

W4393303675_s0692.English Original: Does it disguise, conceal, or reveal the body?

W4393303675_s0693.English Original: The tightness of her bodice showcases her breasts in a conservative manner, while her fitted shirt sleeves appear to explode from the body in the areas with slashing in which the camicia blouses out.

W4393303675_s0694.English Original: Caterina is depicted in a gown that covers large portions of her body with the only part revealed with the table in front of her is her hands and the area around her collar bone.

W4393303675_s0695.English Original: Has the artist taken liberties with the visual representation of the sitter?

W4393303675_s0696.English Original: Is the body elongated or distorted in anyway?

W4393303675_s0697.English Original: If so, consider whether this distortion reflects norms of beauty for the period.

W4393303675_s0698.English Original: Her shoulders are sloped at an angle far too steep for a real human, possibly in an effort to foreground her shoulder that is facing towards the viewer.

W4393303675_s0699.English Original: Additionally, from the angle of the viewer her waist appears to be as wide as her head.

W4393303675_s0700.English Original: She also has an elongated neck, which could be a real depiction or an artistic convention to meet period beauty standards (Birth of Venus by Botticelli, Venus has a very long neck).

W4393303675_s0701.English Original: What was the impetus to examine this artwork(s)?

W4393303675_s0702.English Original: Were you interested in the artist, elements of the dress, or the person(s) in the image?

W4393303675_s0703.English Original: This artwork depicted Caterina Sforza and resides in the collection in Forli (her notorious home).

W4393303675_s0704.English Original: The depiction showcases her at the beginning of her first marriage, and depicts her rather simply for a Sforza daughter.

W4393303675_s0705.English Original: Do you have an emotive reaction to the image?

W4393303675_s0706.English Original: Does it appeal to you or repulse you?

W4393303675_s0707.English Original: Does it remind you of something else?

W4393303675_s0709.English Original: This painting appeals to me as it serves as a mystery.

W4393303675_s0711.English Original: Why doesn't she have any jewelry on?

W4393303675_s0712.English Original: Why is she in a gown that objectively is 50+ years off trend?

W4393303675_s0713.English Original: Why is she in a gown that is so simple?

W4393303675_s0715.English Original: This painting reminds me of Renaissance depictions of the Virgin Mary in period dress, or noblewomen having their likeness depicted as the Virgin Mary or as goddesses.

W4393303675_s0732.English Original: Is there something notable or exceptional about this work?

W4393303675_s0733.English Original: a. Vasari (1550 or 1568) along with Brewer (1970) offer insight into the life and art.

W4393303675_s0734.English Original: Credi, a pupil of Andrea Verrocchio (a peer of Leonardo da Vinci), mimicked the styles of his two famous mentors.

W4393303675_s0735.English Original: The faces of Credi's female portraits are very similar to that of Da Vinci's (Vasari, 15501568).

W4393303675_s0736.English Original: So much so that there was much debate surrounding the similarities between Da Vinci's portrait of Ginevra d'Amerigo dei Benci and Credi's La Giovane Vedova (Brewer, 1970).

W4393303675_s0737.English Original: This painting of Caterina showcases Credi's noted intentionality and care with colors (Brewer, 1970; Vasari, 1550 1568).

W4393303675_s0738.English Original: Of note is his use of green and greenery in the background of his works, which is especially evident in this portrait with it's elaborate landscape.

W4393303675_s0739.English Original: Is it known whether or not the artist worked with artist's mannequins, live models, and/or owned or hired costumes?

W4393303675_s0740.English Original: a. Credi is noted as having created sketch as preparatory studies before creating a painting or altarpiece (Brewer, 1970; Vasari, 15501568).

W4393303675_s0741.English Original: Aside from this information he was noted for conducting sketch studies with clay models in his early career, but it is unknown what his practices were at the time of this portrait (Vasari, 15501568).

W4393303675_s0751.English Original:
Interpretation

 1. Review the material that you have recorded in your observation and reflection on artwork.

W4393303675_s0753.English Original: a. Caterina's depiction as a widow still sticks in my head.

W4393303675_s0754.English Original: However, De Vries provides an in depth explanation to the rationale behind the idea that Caterina herself was okay with this depiction in many ways.

W4393303675_s0755.English Original: Also Sciorina's artistic abilities later in his life are not no par with what Vasari described as promising, and his composition shows it.

W4393303675_s0756.English Original: Does this work provoke n emotive reaction, connect to your background or interests, or otherwise inspire a research question or questions?

W4393303675_s0757.English Original: After all of the research I have done on Sciorina and this portrait, the one reaction I have is anger.

W4393303675_s0758.English Original: It is in essence not an original composition (how could it be as it is a post humous composition), however Sciorina essentially copied the exact depictions of Caterina and Giovanni from two depictions from distinctly different periods in the two individual's lives.

W4393303675_s0759.English Original: These copied individuals are even wearing the same clothes!

W4393303675_s0760.English Original: This painting does provide a very interesting example for my research questions.

W4393303675_s0761.English Original: What does the work have to say about the artist and the visual traditions of the period in which it was made?

W4393303675_s0762.English Original: Frankly, this work shows that Sciorina got lazy in his "old age" and lacks the skills taught to him by his mentor and all around one of the most celebrated artists of the Renaissance if not the entire premodern era, Bronzino.

W4393303675_s0763.English Original: His work lacks the clarity and intense attention to detail as that of his other 16th century peers.

W4393303675_s0764.English Original: What does the depiction of fashion in the artwork say about the culture of the period?

W4393303675_s0765.English Original: The dress worn by Caterina informs us that even dress as simplistic as a black dress and mourning veil has power.

W4393303675_s0766.English Original: Consider the artwork and the fashions depicted therein in relation to a conceptual framework or lens of interpretation that is linked to your research focus.

W4393303675_s0767.English Original: Identify that framework here and briefly consider one or more key texts related to that theory.

W4393303675_s0768.English Original: The suggested frames of references include, but not limited to: status, modernity, ideals of beauty, identity, including gender, sexuality, or ethnicity, politics of representation, and globalization.

W4393303675_s0769.English Original: a. Caterina Sforza (14631509), born into the Sforza empire as the illegitimate daughter of Galeazzo Sforza and Lucrezia Landriani, was raised in one of the most affluent courts of the time (de Vries, 2003).

W4393303675_s0770.English Original: Having been legitimized, in 1477 she was married to Girolamo Riario, a nephew of then Pope Sixtus IV (Hairston, 2000).

W4393303675_s0771.English Original:
Her first marriage produced seven children before her

husband was assassinated in April of 1488.

W4393303675_s0772.English Original: Following the infamous siege of Forlì (mentioned above), Caterina maintained the appearance of a widow, as she acted as regent for her eldest son Ottaviano who was only 9 years old at the time of his father's death.

W4393303675_s0773.English Original: Caterina's shrewd and cunning diplomat as she ruled Forlì and Imola and protected them from domestic and foreign invasions.

W4393303675_s0774.English Original: Machevelli even features Caterina in a number of his writings depicting her as the cunning, cold, woman that would let her children die to protect her rule of Romagna.

W4393303675_s0775.English Original: Despite this impressive resume, she maintained the garb of a widow in official depictions of herself including a selfcommissioned coin following the approval of her regency in 1488 (de Vries, 2003).

W4393303675_s0776.English Original: Period accounts of the Forlì siege highlight this value of her regency over her children as Caterina is said to have claimed that if the captors wished to kill her children they could as she could always have another (although some accounts claim she said she was pregnant) (Hairston, 2000).

W4393303675_s0777.English Original: This in conjunction with the rumors surrounding the murders of two of her spouses and the early death of the third do not appear to add up to the loyal and devoted widow persona that Caterina continuously portrayed.

W4393303675_s0778.English Original: However, De Vries (2017), highlights the fact that her widow persona was directly tied to her identity as regent of Forlì and Imola.

W4393303675_s0779.English Original: In maintaining the appearance of a widow and then "single" matron throughout her life she asserted her power and legitimacy to rule, (which she maintained even after her eldest son came of age).

W4393303675_s0780.English Original: The depiction of Caterina as a widow in this painting takes from a depiction of her following the death of her third husband Giovanni Pier Francesco de' Medici.

W4393303675_s0781.English Original: In opposition to previous depictions of her, she lacks any identifying features of who she is mourning, as he is "alive" right next to her.

W4393303675_s0782.English Original: While Sciorina's depiction of Caterina mourning her "alive" husband lacks common sense, in a way it unintentionally lends to narrative established by Caterina in 1488: perception is power, and power is communicated through dress.

W4393303675_s0783.English Original: Following Giovanni's death Caterina was now mother to the only male son of Giovanni, as a result, Caterina became the grandmother of the next leading power in the Medici family, Cosimo I de' Medici, the first Duke of Tuscany, and husband to Eleonora di Toledo.

W4393303675_s0784.English Original: So despite Sciorina's intentions to depict Caterina in a subservient light, her dress still communicates the manner in which Caterina established her own lasting identity as a powerful woman in life, and inadvertently in death as well.

 Observations

 1.

W4393303675_s0786.English Original: What is the title of the artwork?

This work was created by Ambrogio de De Predis

W4393303675_s0793.English Original: What year was the work created?

W4393303675_s0794.English Original: This work is credited to likely have been created in 1493.

W4393303675_s0795.English Original: Is it part of a series (a multiple, a reproduction)?

W4393303675_s0796.English Original: This portrait was not part of a series.

W4393303675_s0797.English Original: 6. Who owns it now (museum, private collector, institution, gallery)?

W4393303675_s0798.English Original: The National Portrait Gallery in the United States currently owns the portrait.

W4393303675_s0799.English Original: What are the dimensions of the work (framed and/or unframed)?

W4393303675_s0800.English Original: Is the work largescale or smallscale relative to the human body?

W4393303675_s0801.English Original: The painting itself is 20 1/6 inches by 12 13/16 inches.

W4393303675_s0802.English Original: Is the work horizontal or vertical in orientation?

W4393303675_s0803.English Original: Consider how this orientation impacts the work.

W4393303675_s0804.English Original: The work is in the vertical orientation, which is consistent with the style for portraits.

W4393303675_s0805.English Original: Has this work been altered in some way from its original state?

W4393303675_s0806.English Original: It is unknown if any alterations have been made to the painting.

W4393303675_s0807.English Original: However, it does not appear to be seriously altered.

W4393303675_s0808.English Original: Where is the emphasis in the image?

W4393303675_s0809.English Original: The emphasis is on her hair and her gown.

W4393303675_s0811.English Original: The elaborate headdress that covers part of her head and the entirety of her ponytail is what catches my attention first.

W4393303675_s0812.English Original: How many persons are included in the artwork?

W4393303675_s0813.English Original: There is one person in this portrait.

W4393303675_s0814.English Original: Are the figures in the artwork known persons?

W4393303675_s0815.English Original: Is the work intended as a portrait?

W4393303675_s0816.English Original: Can they be identified by name?

W4393303675_s0817.English Original: If so, this knowledge of their identity inform your analysis?

W4393303675_s0818.English Original: The person in this portrait is Bianca Maria Sforza.

W4393303675_s0819.English Original: This knowledge aids in identifying discreet motifs that reference her identity.

W4393303675_s0820.English Original: If there is more than one person, what is their physical position relative to each other?

W4393303675_s0821.English Original: Does their position, posture, or body language echo their relationship?

W4393303675_s0822.English Original: There is only one person in this portrait.

W4393303675_s0824.English Original: a. Bianca's gaze is directed through the left side of the portrait.

W4393303675_s0825.English Original: Is the setting indoors or outdoors?

W4393303675_s0826.English Original: The setting is undetermined as the background is completely black/dark.

W4393303675_s0827.English Original: Does the artwork depict a specific place or setting?

W4393303675_s0828.English Original: The setting is completely blacked out so the setting cannot be determined as a specific place.

W4393303675_s0829.English Original: What elements of the setting or background are notable?

W4393303675_s0830.English Original: The background has no notable elements as it is blacked out.

W4393303675_s0831.English Original: Does the setting convey status, privilege, or other meaning?

W4393303675_s0832.English Original: The plain background creates a chiaroscuro effect which further highlights Bianca, and gives the impression of her being angel like or royal.

W4393303675_s0833.English Original: Are the people in the artwork clothed?

W4393303675_s0834.English Original: If not, are the naked bodies ornamented or fashioned in some way?

W4393303675_s0836.English Original: How are the people oriented (front facing, threequarter view, profile, or back facing)?

W4393303675_s0838.English Original: a. Bianca is in complete profile.

W4393303675_s0839.English Original: This can be viewed as a very regal or imperial choice as many Roman Emperors and other highranking aristocrats were frequently depicted in profile, especially on coins.

W4393303675_s0840.English Original: This profile position signifies not only wealth, but part of her regal status as the daughter of one of the most powerful dukedoms in Europe at the time.

W4393303675_s0841.English Original: What is the gender of each person in the image?

W4393303675_s0842.English Original: Has the artist emphasized gender or obscured it?

W4393303675_s0844.English Original: Her femineity his especially emphasized in the elaborateness in which her hair is decorated and the abundance of pearls she is wearing.

W4393303675_s0845.English Original: Consider the posture of the sitter(s).

W4393303675_s0846.English Original: Are they seated, standing, or reclining?

W4393303675_s0847.English Original: Are parts of the body not visible in the image?

W4393303675_s0848.English Original: Is their posture rigid or relaxed?

W4393303675_s0849.English Original: Is posture indicative of state of mind and/or training of the body?

W4393303675_s0850.English Original: From her profile position she appears to be sitting up exceptionally straight, with her head held high with no slouching, and her arms sat at her side.

W4393303675_s0851.English Original: This very formal and elegant posture is indicative of a high class upbringing in which etiquette lessons would have included.

W4393303675_s0852.English Original: Are other objects or animals included in the image to depict activities, interest, or status,…?

W4393303675_s0853.English Original: How does the sitter engage with these objects?

W4393303675_s0854.English Original: There appears to be a red flower in her girdle on the side.

W4393303675_s0855.English Original: This could be indicative of her affinity to flowers or possibly a Sforza emblem.

W4393303675_s0856.English Original: Describe the main elements of clothing for each person in the image in detail, noting the garment category and how it is worn.

W4393303675_s0857.English Original: Also note whether any outdoor clothing.

W4393303675_s0858.English Original: a. Bianca is wearing a brocade gold overgown, a white camicia underneath the overgown, her sleeves feature period slashing in which the camicia is visible, and her sleeve is tied into the shoulder seam with black ribbons.

W4393303675_s0859.English Original: Can the type of textiles be determined?

W4393303675_s0860.English Original: Does the artist attempt to convey the nature of the textile,…?

W4393303675_s0861.English Original: Note the colors and dominant patterns in the textiles used for the clothing.

W4393303675_s0862.English Original: The base fabric of Bianca's gown appears to be some form of brocade (possibly velvet due to the specific brush marks that indicate a pile weave), while her camicia is most likely made of white silk or linen.

W4393303675_s0863.English Original:
In Bianca's brocade gown there are a number of natural elements including the symbolic

motif of pomegranate (there are three of them depicted together on tree stumps in numerous places) and the ogee lattice.

W4393303675_s0864.English Original: Is the clothing embellished in any way with fur, lace, jewels, embroidery, braid, or beading?

W4393303675_s0865.English Original: It appears that Bianca's gown is possibly embroidered or brocade, however her headdress features an abundance of pearls, diamonds, and other jewels.

W4393303675_s0866.English Original: Is any element of dress exaggerated?

W4393303675_s0867.English Original: No element of dress appears to be exaggerated.

W4393303675_s0868.English Original: Describe the accessories of each person…Note how they are worn, carried, or placed in the image.

W4393303675_s0869.English Original: a. Bianca is wearing an elaborate headdress with gold floral shaped metal netting embellished with pearls, diamonds and other gemstones.

W4393303675_s0870.English Original: One cluster of jewels that hangs over her left ear has a piece of cloth wrapped intwined with the group of jewels that says "merito et tempore [With merit and time]" a Sforza motto.

W4393303675_s0871.English Original: This headdress sits halfway back on her head and appears to connect to the string of white and grey pearls that wrap around gold fabric that encases her body length ponytail.

W4393303675_s0872.English Original: She also wears a plain black string ferronière (possibly in which the grouping of jewels is attached to), which is tied to her head with the excess string hanging down to her left shoulder.

W4393303675_s0873.English Original: Bianca is also wearing a white pearl necklace with two jewels (one rectangular and black, and the other orange and circular) hanging off with a large oval pearl at the end which sits on the collar of her dress.

W4393303675_s0874.English Original: She also appears to be wearing another black string necklace underneath this more elaborate one, which disappears underneath the neckline of her gown, possibly hinting at a crucifix necklace.

W4393303675_s0875.English Original: Finally, Bianca appears to be wearing a jeweled girdle with a red carnation flower tucked into it.

W4393303675_s0876.English Original: The girdle features a pattern of four pearls surrounding a larger rectangular stone imposed on a gold circular mount.

W4393303675_s0877.English Original: Are there visible signifiers of rank or status such as jewelry, metals, swords, or armor?

W4393303675_s0878.English Original: The inclusion of her family motto on her headdress is a large visible signifier of her status as part of the Sforza family.

W4393303675_s0879.English Original: Furthermore, the truly abundant jewelry Bianca is wearing in this painting hints at a high level of wealth and status.

W4393303675_s0880.English Original: The red carnation tucked into Bianca's girdle showcases her identity as a bride (or soon to be bride), as the carnation in Northern Italian art during this period was symbolic for marriage (Meagher, 2007).

W4393303675_s0881.English Original: Does the clothing serve as an occupational uniform or marker of identity?

W4393303675_s0882.English Original: The clothing serves as a marker of her identity as the daughter of a very wealthy and of high social standing (Duke of Milan) man.

W4393303675_s0883.English Original: Describe the hairstyle and makeup of each person.

W4393303675_s0884.English Original: a. Bianca is depicted with her hair in a wrapped jeweled ponytail (this style is known as the coazzone braid), and loosely hanging hair on the side of her face that covers her ear (Welch, 2009).

W4393303675_s0885.English Original: De Predis depicts a few stray hairs from the others that fall at an angle down her left cheek.

W4393303675_s0886.English Original: Bianca does not appear to be wearing any makeup, and her eyebrows appear almost transparent (possibly a result of her correspondingly auburn/ red hair).

W4393303675_s0887.English Original: Is this a realistic or abstracted image?

W4393303675_s0889.English Original: Are any parts of the image unfinished or indistinguishable?

W4393303675_s0890.English Original: The painting appears to be complete in all aspects.

W4393303675_s0891.English Original: Does the artwork fit within a certain stylistic period in art history?

W4393303675_s0892.English Original: If so, is it consistent with the dominant characteristics of that style?

W4393303675_s0893.English Original: This painting fits within the beginning of the High Renaissance emphasis on humanism that corresponds to artistic interests in classicalism (a possible explanation of the profile portrait).

W4393303675_s0894.English Original: The high level attention to the details of her dress, the distinct light source (from the left pointing directly onto her face), and the realistic depiction of the human body are all characteristic of art during this period that are visually present in this portrait.

W4393303675_s0895.English Original: What is the sense of space in the work?

W4393303675_s0898.English Original: Is the sense of space literal or indeterminate?

W4393303675_s0899.English Original: There is no distinguishable background as it is all black.

W4393303675_s0900.English Original: This choice creates a distinct foreground, in which Bianca sits in profile, and a distinct background, the space to the right of Bianca in the space of the portrait.

W4393303675_s0901.English Original: The sense of space around Bianca is indeterminate as it is all blacked out, so the viewer must draw conclusions about the blackedout background.

W4393303675_s0902.English Original: This in itself draws questions about the actuality of a physical black background existing at the time Bianca sat for the portrait.

W4393303675_s0903.English Original: Has perspective been distorted or altered for specific effect?

W4393303675_s0904.English Original: Perspective does not appear to be altered in a specific or major way.

W4393303675_s0905.English Original: What is the scale of the artwork relative to the human body and does this create the illusion of space or evoke a feeling or affect?

W4393303675_s0906.English Original: The size of the portrait is closer to 1/3 of human size.

W4393303675_s0907.English Original: In a way depending on how tall Bianca was this portrait could be close to life sized.

W4393303675_s0908.English Original: As this is a speculated marriage request portrait it is possible that this was intended to be as close to realistic of her size as possible.

W4393303675_s0909.English Original: Furthermore, the size of the painting and the orientation in which Bianca sits creates the effect of the viewer turning to the side and seeing Bianca seated next to them.

W4393303675_s0910.English Original: How was space used to contain the representation of the body?

W4393303675_s0911.English Original: Think of the lines within the artwork and how they echo or contain space around the bodies.

W4393303675_s0912.English Original: Due to the blackedout background the only framing of the body occurring in this portrait is through the bounds of the campus.

W4393303675_s0913.English Original: The choice of utilizing chiaroscuro to focus on Bianca is a straightforward use of the technique in portraiture.

W4393303675_s0914.English Original: In essence, the way in which the body is situated in blackness achieves the portrait's purpose, to focus on Bianca's appearance.

W4393303675_s0915.English Original: Does the use of color bring attention t certain forms, create movement, or generate a mood?

W4393303675_s0916.English Original: The use of golds, blacks, and whites highlights numerous aspects of her dress while in many ways sidelining her facial appearance (possibly purposeful as her appearance was noted as not being the most beautiful (Rill, 1968).

W4393303675_s0917.English Original: The use of white in the pearls all down her ponytail, around her neck and on her headpiece draws the viewer's eyes from the front of her face moving all the way down her back.

W4393303675_s0918.English Original: As similar effect is seen with the stark black, orange/brown jewels, and white pearls on her girdle.

W4393303675_s0919.English Original:
The colors create a

slight contrast from her gown and help in leading the eye to the red flower tucked into the belt.

W4393303675_s0920.English Original: Finally, the color white is similarly utilized on her camicia which is depicted coming out of her tied and attached sleeve.

W4393303675_s0921.English Original: This color in the midst of brocaded gold and black ribbons creates a sense of color balance with her pale skin.

W4393303675_s0922.English Original: What does the artist emphasize visually?

W4393303675_s0924.English Original: The artist is emphasizing the ornamentation Bianca is wearing.

W4393303675_s0925.English Original: It is easily assumed that the artist did this as the intended recipients of the portrait would most likely care more about the wealth and political connections Bianca could bring to their court and less about her beauty.

W4393303675_s0926.English Original: However, beauty of a intended bride was still an important factor for many aristocratic men (at least those that could afford to care), and this could be the motivation behind De Predis depicting Bianca in profile as she was not considered to be exceptionally beautiful (Rill, 1968).

W4393303675_s0927.English Original: How does the artist emphasize this aspect?

W4393303675_s0929.English Original: The artist emphasized this utilizing color (as explained in Observation question 40) and a heightened attention to the rendering of her expense brocade gown, and numerous jewels.

W4393303675_s0930.English Original: In a way he also utilizes scale to emphasize other elements of her dress over her own physical facial features.

W4393303675_s0931.English Original: Her jeweled headdress that appears to connect to her jeweled ponytail seems to dwarf her unadorned and makeup free face.

W4393303675_s0932.English Original: While this is not a physical dwarfing, it is more of a compositional dwarfing, with numerous elements of adornment concentrated in other parts of the portrait.

W4393303675_s0933.English Original: Of course this could be reflective of garments and accessories Bianca actual wore while sitting for this portrait, and less about De Predis's compositional skills.

W4393303675_s0934.English Original: Is there an underlying rhythm, pattern, or geometric structure to the composition?

W4393303675_s0935.English Original: While the only thing within the composition is Bianca, there are some underlying geometric structures within her garments and accessories.

W4393303675_s0936.English Original: Triangles appear frequently in Bianca's garments, most prominently in the pearls wrapped around her ponytail, and again in the lacing in of her sleeve to the rest of the gown.

W4393303675_s0937.English Original: Is there a sense of balance or has the artist deliberately chosen to destabilize the composition?

W4393303675_s0938.English Original: The portrait appears to be balanced as Bianca is centered within the canvas and there are no other elements in the portrait besides Bianca to destabilize the composition.

W4393303675_s0939.English Original: However, the fact that Bianca is depicted in profile means that the portrait, while seemingly balanced, is not symmetrical.

W4393303675_s0940.English Original: The balance however is still found with the heavily jeweled ponytail in headdress to the right of the composition, but her necklace, girdle, and brocade gown featuring prominently on the left side of the portrait.

W4393303675_s0942.English Original: Do the elements appear integrated or separate from each other?

W4393303675_s0943.English Original: The unity of this portrait can be owed to the color balance.

W4393303675_s0944.English Original:
While there are examples of contrasting colors, her gown is a great example of the unity and

 interaction of separate elements.

W4393303675_s0945.English Original: Her girdle and gown, while featuring different textures and colors, come across in a unified manner.

W4393303675_s0946.English Original: What do you think the artist is trying to express in this artwork?

W4393303675_s0948.English Original: The artist is very clearly trying to demonstrate that Bianca is a legitimate daughter of the last Duke of Milan, and she is from an extremely wealthy family, in addition to recently having married the Holy Roman Emperor Maximilian (National Gallery of Art, n.d.b).

W4393303675_s0949.English Original: The fact that the composition does not require any background elements to help facilitate this purpose, is indicative of the level of wealth displayed in Bianca's appearance.

W4393303675_s0950.English Original: Does the choice of medium impact the work in a material way?

W4393303675_s0951.English Original: The choice of medium impacts the work in that it is consistent with the medium of portraiture during this period.

W4393303675_s0952.English Original: How has the artist used rest to define the profession, class, status, racial, or gender identity of the sitter?

W4393303675_s0953.English Original: The artist does not really use rest to define the identity of the sitter as this is conveyed in other ways.

W4393303675_s0954.English Original: However, as previously mentioned her position in profile could have been used to disguise her true facial appearance and to hint at her royal identity.

W4393303675_s0955.English Original: Is the dress of each sitter consistent with his or her gender, age, class, and occupation?

W4393303675_s0956.English Original: The dress that Bianca is depicted in is especially consistent with her identity.

W4393303675_s0957.English Original: Are the garments stylistically consistent with the period in which the artwork was created?

W4393303675_s0958.English Original: The garments that Bianca wears in this portrait are consistent with those worn during this period in Milan.

W4393303675_s0959.English Original: Do the garments depicted have stylistic, religious, artistic, or iconic references?

W4393303675_s0960.English Original: The jeweled ponytail style that Bianca wears in this portrait is possibly an iconic reference to her mother Bona of Savoy and her aunt Beatrice d'Este (who is credited for bringing the style to Milan) who were depicted in numerous other depictions with the same coazzone braid hair style.

W4393303675_s0961.English Original: Her aunt was notably depicted in this style in the Sant' Ambrogio ad Nemus altarpiece in the Pala Sforzesca in 1494 which depicts Bianca's uncle's investiture as regent over the dukedom of Milan (following her father's assassination).

W4393303675_s0962.English Original: How does the clothing shape and fashion the body?

W4393303675_s0963.English Original: Does it disguise, conceal, or reveal the body?

W4393303675_s0964.English Original: a. Bianca's clothing and accessories disguise and hide many elements of her body.

W4393303675_s0965.English Original: While much of this is due to period stylistic conventions and ideas on modesty, the choice to depict Bianca in profile hides more of her body and face than her garments and hair do.

W4393303675_s0966.English Original: Has the artist taken liberties with the visual representation of the sitter?

W4393303675_s0967.English Original: Is the body elongated or distorted in anyway?

W4393303675_s0968.English Original: If so, consider whether this distortion reflects norms of beauty for the period.

W4393303675_s0969.English Original: The artist does not appear to have take any liberties with the visual representation of the sitter in terms of altering her physical appearance.

W4393303675_s0970.English Original: Her body appears to be proportional for a realistic human depiction.

W4393303675_s0971.English Original: What was the impetus to examine this artwork(s)?

W4393303675_s0972.English Original: Were you interested in the artist, elements of the dress, or the person(s) in the image?

W4393303675_s0973.English Original: This work was examined as it represents a pivotal depiction of Italian Renaissance portraiture, but also provides an intriguing data collection site for dress identity data on Bianca Maria Sforza prior to her second marriage.

W4393303675_s0974.English Original: Do you have an emotive reaction to the image?

W4393303675_s0975.English Original: Does it appeal to you or repulse you?

W4393303675_s0976.English Original: Does it remind you of something else?

W4393303675_s0977.English Original: Upon seeing this image I am in awe at not only the amount of detail in which De Predis took in rendering Bianca's likeness, but in the amount of jewelry and adornment she is presented in which are also carefully rendered.

W4393303675_s0978.English Original: Do your personal reactions indicate that cultural beliefs have shifted?

W4393303675_s0979.English Original: a. I do not believe my personal reaction does not really indicate a shift in cultural beliefs.

W4393303675_s0980.English Original: Can you identify a personal connection to this work or a bias that should be acknowledge in your research?

W4393303675_s0981.English Original: a. I believe the only bias I have is reading numerous accounts of how Bianca was not considered beautiful by her contemporaries, yet I believe this painting depicts her as objectively beautiful (in profile at least).

W4393303675_s0982.English Original: Is this a single work or part of a series?

W4393303675_s0983.English Original: If it is a series, how many are in the series?

W4393303675_s0984.English Original: This work appears to be a single work.

W4393303675_s0985.English Original: Has the artist created other works that are not part of a series but are otherwise similar to this work?

W4393303675_s0986.English Original: If so, list them here and consider what might be learned from this comparison.

W4393303675_s0987.English Original: Portrait of a Young Woman (n.d.): This painting, frequently believed to be Beatrice d'Este depicts the woman in profile, in much the similar positioning as Bianca.

W4393303675_s0988.English Original: This could be indicative of a composition style favored by De Predis than a preference in her own depiction (Wilcox, 1920).

W4393303675_s0989.English Original: Portrait of a Woman in Profile (14951499): This portrait is explained to be most likely be of a noblewoman (possibly Ludovico's illegitimate daughter Biana Giovanna) at the Milanese court of Duke Ludovico Sforza (Bianca's uncle)., as De Predis was a court painter there at the time.

W4393303675_s0990.English Original: The less sophisticated dress of this woman really drives home the purposeful opulence in which Bianca is depicted (The National Gallery, n.d.).

W4393303675_s0991.English Original: c. Bianca Maria Sforza (14721510), Empress, profile portrait (14931495): This portrait showcases Bianca with the coazzone braid in a period after her marriage and move to modern day Germany.

W4393303675_s0992.English Original: This could signify an adherence to her home dress traditions despite also acclimating to her husband's court attire.

W4393303675_s0993.English Original: This 14931495 portrait depicts her in notably less jewelry and less ornamented garments, which could be indicative of this portrait showcasing Bianca in dress closer to that she would have worn everyday.

W4393303675_s0994.English Original: This portrait, being dated to around her marriage could be indictive that while the 149395 portrait is Bianca's typical dress identity, this portrait represents her dress for celebrating/ promoting this momentous occasion.

consider whether or not this work is consistent with the artist's oeuvre.

W4393303675_s0997.English Original: Is there something notable or exceptional about this work?

W4393303675_s0998.English Original: As there is only one verified painting via signature created by De Predis (although numerous others have been formally credited to him due to the stylistic similarities).

W4393303675_s0999.English Original: However, De Predis was notably a court painter in the dukedom of Milan and painted portraits of numerous members of the Sforza family.

W4393303675_s1000.English Original:
De De Predis was also known to be a student of Leonardo da Vinci (The National Gallery, n.d.; National Gallery of Art, n.d.b)
 21.

W4393303675_s1001.English Original: Is it known whether or not the artist worked with artist's mannequins, live models, and/or owned or hired costumes?

W4393303675_s1002.English Original: It is unknown what method De De Predis used to create his portraits, however as the court painter from this period De De Predis would likely have painted the first few layers from Bianca being a live model.

W4393303675_s1008.English Original: Please reference other De Predis portrait in this research.

W4393303675_s1009.English Original: Identify any related or similar garments from dress history texts.

W4393303675_s1010.English Original: Does this work reflect a specific event from history or mark a notable shift in attitudes about gender, beauty, or identity?

W4393303675_s1012.English Original: Additionally, as de Predis only remained at the Habsburg court with Bianca for a few years into her marriage, this portrait could speak to her evolving dress identity as she adapts to a style that is less distinctly Italian, yet still wears key Milanese and Italian accessories.

W4393303675_s1013.English Original:
Interpretation

 1. Review the material that you have recorded in your observation and reflection on artwork.

W4393303675_s1015.English Original: The gold necklace pendant still sticks out to me as I was unable to identify the symbolism of the silver crosses on the pendant.

W4393303675_s1016.English Original: Additionally, I found the color blocking of her gown and sleeve.

W4393303675_s1017.English Original: From my own research this style would not have been common in Italian Renaissance dress of the period.

W4393303675_s1018.English Original: Does this work provoke n emotive reaction, connect to your background or interests, or otherwise inspire a research question or questions?

W4393303675_s1019.English Original: This work aids in answering my preestablished research question and endeavor to identify the evolution of Bianca Maria Sforza's dress identity in numerous periods of her life.

W4393303675_s1020.English Original: What does the work have to say about the artist and the visual traditions of the period in which it was made?

W4393303675_s1021.English Original: This artwork aligns with period portraiture conventions in Italy and by de Predis.

W4393303675_s1022.English Original: Her profile depiction, her dress, and even the depiction of her hair aligns with period sentiments.

W4393303675_s1023.English Original: What does the depiction of fashion in the artwork say about the culture of the period?

W4393303675_s1024.English Original: The fashion and dress in this portrait highlights the Italian Renaissance emphasis on construction details over brocade or complex textiles.

W4393303675_s1025.English Original: Consider the artwork and the fashions depicted therein in relation to a conceptual framework or lens of interpretation that is linked to your research focus.

W4393303675_s1026.English Original: Identify that framework here and briefly consider one or more key texts related to that theory.

W4393303675_s1027.English Original: The suggested frames of references include, but not limited to: status, modernity, ideals of beauty, identity, including gender, sexuality, or ethnicity, politics of representation, and globalization.

W4393303675_s1028.English Original: At the time of the painting of this portrait, Bianca was likely within two years of her marriage to Maximillian.

W4393303675_s1029.English Original: However, Bianca and Masimillian did not live together until 1494, which could indicate why this portrait depicts her still in a majority Italian and Milanese style of dress.

W4393303675_s1030.English Original: Considering that Bianca's dowry was utilized to fund her husband's military exploits in the first two years of their marriage and the fact that the couple lived apart, one can conclude that in the eyes of Maximillian, Bianca served her purpose (providing an enormous influx in wealth to him) and was allowed to live and dress as she pleased (Rill, 1968).

W4393303675_s1031.English Original: Furthermore, the lack of contact with her husband at this point and her pending investiture as Empress, could explain the lack of Habsburg symbolism in her dress identity, as legally she was part of the Habsburg family, however she lived apart from her husband and likely had not been forced to assimilate some aspects of her life to fit with her husband's culture and court.

W4393303675_s1077.English Original: The green tapestry conveys wealth and a level of privilege to be able to afford such a textile, let lone have it placed in a setting that is potentially outside.

W4393303675_s1095.English Original: This posture is indicative of high class breeding/ upbringing, that which would be expected of the daughter of a wealthy and influential duke and the wife of an emperor.

W4393303675_s1109.English Original: The gown itself is red with gold accents, the gold accents take the shape of flames up the shorter sleeves of the outer gown.

W4393303675_s1114.English Original: Describe the accessories of each person…Note how they are worn, carried, or placed in the image.

W4393303675_s1115.English Original: She appears to be wearing pink fitted gloves with top stitching at the thumb seam.

W4393303675_s1116.English Original: She has three rings on her ungloved hand (same as the other Strigel portrait).

W4393303675_s1117.English Original: Bianca is wearing five necklaces: two large circular chain linked necklaces, two braided necklaces (one with a knot on her collarbone), and one large circular chain linked necklace styled as a choker.

W4393303675_s1118.English Original: Her headdress appears to be made of braid with jewels along the front.

W4393303675_s1134.English Original: What is the sense of space in the work?

W4393303675_s1137.English Original: Is the sense of space literal or indeterminate?

W4393303675_s1138.English Original: There are formal distinctions between the foreground (Bianca), the midground (the tapestry), and the background (the landscape outside the window).

W4393303675_s1139.English Original: However, the interactions between these three spaces are tentative at best.

W4393303675_s1140.English Original: Bianca's shadow falls on the tapestry which can be called a very passive interaction between the two spaces, yet there is no such interaction between the foreground and midground and the background which sits as its own entity.

W4393303675_s1141.English Original: It is possible that the window in which we see the background through may not have existed in real life.

W4393303675_s1142.English Original: Has perspective been distorted or altered for specific effect?

W4393303675_s1143.English Original: It does not appear that the perspective has been distorted.

W4393303675_s1144.English Original: What is the scale of the artwork relative to the human body and does this create the illusion of space or evoke a feeling or affect?

W4393303675_s1145.English Original: The portrait is similar in size to a half body portrait, creating a close to life sized effect, and no doubt furthering the feeling of regal elegance and wealth felt when viewing this painting.

W4393303675_s1146.English Original: How was space used to contain the representation of the body?

W4393303675_s1147.English Original: Think of the lines within the artwork and how they echo or contain space around the bodies.

W4393303675_s1148.English Original: The artist utilized line to directly shape the framing of the body.

W4393303675_s1149.English Original: In an arguably obvious technique, the artist positions the tapestry behind Bianca to create an offcenter framing of her body, and creating a balanced composition.

W4393303675_s1150.English Original: The tapestry edge that hangs from the top of the painting aids in further framing the portrait as it creates a border/frame within the composition that draws the eyes back down to Bianca.

W4393303675_s1151.English Original: Does the use of color bring attention t certain forms, create movement, or generate a mood?

W4393303675_s1152.English Original: The abundance of red in the composition allows the viewer's eyes to focus on Bianca.

W4393303675_s1153.English Original: The red not within the garments Bianca is wearing (the red velvet she sits on and the red trim of the tapestry) create a balance of color within the composition and subtly draw the eyes back to the more prominent and rich red hues Bianca is wearing.

W4393303675_s1154.English Original: Furthermore, the white/cream color of her camicia sleeves brings the eye completely on Bianca's body.

W4393303675_s1155.English Original: The bodice piece with the narrative scene in it brings in white and green to the gown (the only location on the gown where these colors are present) drawing the viewer's eye to these colors and this scene.

W4393303675_s1156.English Original: What does the artist emphasize visually?

W4393303675_s1158.English Original: The artist emphasized the elaborateness and the details within Bianca's gown.

W4393303675_s1159.English Original: This is used as a means to convey her status and position within society.

W4393303675_s1160.English Original: How does the artist emphasize this aspect?

W4393303675_s1162.English Original: The artist emphasized this through color, line, and the Humanist details included in the textiles that make up her garments.

W4393303675_s1163.English Original: Is there an underlying rhythm, pattern, or geometric structure to the composition?

W4393303675_s1164.English Original: The composition focuses on rectangular compositions behind Bianca (possible as a method to better frame her within the composition or not distract from her figure in the composition), while her physical seated form creates a triangular structure, with her head serving as the point and the lower half of her body representing the base.

W4393303675_s1165.English Original: This nonright angular element drastically stands out against the rectangular midground and background compositional components.

W4393303675_s1166.English Original: Is there a sense of balance or has the artist deliberately chosen to destabilize the composition?

W4393303675_s1167.English Original: The artist has created a slightly destabilized composition.

W4393303675_s1168.English Original: The lack of symmetry allows for a more targeted emphasis on Bianca.

W4393303675_s1169.English Original:
The fact that she is positioned slightly offcentered to the right while her body is ¾ facing the left

side of the portrait allows the eyes to sweep down the body at an angle from the upper right hand of the portrait to the lower left side.

W4393303675_s1171.English Original: Do the elements appear integrated or separate from each other?

W4393303675_s1172.English Original: This painting lacks some elements of unity.

W4393303675_s1173.English Original: The quality of the background and midground elements of the composition create a disjointed emphasis.

W4393303675_s1174.English Original: While the key figure of the portrait is put to the forefront the other elements are so onedimensional it disrupts the integration of all the elements of the painting.

W4393303675_s1175.English Original: What do you think the artist is trying to express in this artwork?

W4393303675_s1177.English Original: a. I believe the artist is trying to emphasize the grandeur and wealth of Bianca and her husband as emperor and empress.

W4393303675_s1178.English Original: The richness of the fabric, garments, and accessories Bianca is depicted wearing easily conveys this goal.

W4393303675_s1179.English Original: Does the choice of medium impact the work in a material way?

W4393303675_s1180.English Original: The choice of medium does not impact the work, but rather adheres to period artistic/ portrait conventions.

W4393303675_s1181.English Original: How has the artist used rest to define the profession, class, status, racial, or gender identity of the sitter?

W4393303675_s1182.English Original: The formal pose in which Bianca is depicted (head up, arms/ hands purposefully crossed) presents a very regal persona.

W4393303675_s1183.English Original: This is especially true when one considers the precariously positioned headdress she wears, as it would require lots of practice and breeding to sit straight with such an accessory.

W4393303675_s1184.English Original: Is the dress of each sitter consistent with his or her gender, age, class, and occupation?

W4393303675_s1185.English Original: The dress of Bianca is highly consistent with her position as the daughter of a high powered duke and wife to the Holy Roman Emperor, and as such the Holy Roman Empress.

W4393303675_s1186.English Original: Are the garments stylistically consistent with the period in which the artwork was created?

W4393303675_s1187.English Original: The gown that Bianca is wearing straddles the line between consistent and inconsistent elements.

W4393303675_s1188.English Original: The extremely long and voluminous nature of the camicia sleeves and the waistline closer to an empire line are both more consistent with styles seen in the Late Middle ages or early Italian Renaissance (circa earlymid 15th century).

W4393303675_s1189.English Original: Do the garments depicted have stylistic, religious, artistic, or iconic references?

W4393303675_s1190.English Original: One can infer that the inclusion of peacocks and the flamelike motifs are meant to signify strong royal/ aristocratic rule or lineage.

W4393303675_s1191.English Original: The styles she are wearing align with those worn in Northern Europe during the period, and a nod to the latent fashion advances present in Northern Europe at a time that marked the High Renaissance in Italy and arguably the beginning of the Northern Renaissance.

W4393303675_s1192.English Original: How does the clothing shape and fashion the body?

W4393303675_s1193.English Original: Does it disguise, conceal, or reveal the body?

W4393303675_s1194.English Original: The sleeve styles completely disguise the middle section of Bianca's arms, while dwarfing her hands.

W4393303675_s1195.English Original:
This might be a possible attempt at

making her hands appear more dainty and align with Northern Renaissance beauty ideals in respect to hands (Welch, 2011).

W4393303675_s1196.English Original: Notably in this depiction of Bianca the size of her sleeves, the waistline cut, and the position of her arms all conceal or aim to take attention away from her stomach/womb, a possible indicator of her motherless status a mere one to five years before her death.

W4393303675_s1197.English Original: Has the artist taken liberties with the visual representation of the sitter?

W4393303675_s1198.English Original: Is the body elongated or distorted in anyway?

W4393303675_s1199.English Original: If so, consider whether this distortion reflects norms of beauty for the period.

W4393303675_s1200.English Original: The body does not appear to be distorted or misrepresented in any noticeable way.

W4393303675_s1201.English Original: However, her face does appear to be very young for an individual that was between the ages of 33 and 38 in this depiction.

W4393303675_s1202.English Original: She instead appears to look like a teenager or in her early 20s, and definitely not the sickly ugly woman that was described at the time of her marriage to Emperor Maximillian.

W4393303675_s1203.English Original: This altered depiction could be a choice of vanity, an attempt to depict Bianca as appearing closer to her portraits from her youth (those commissioned prior to her marriage to Emperor Maximillian).

W4393303675_s1206.English Original: This artwork was examined because it showcases Bianca in distinctly Northern European style of dress and provides interesting data in an effort to answer my research question.

W4393303675_s1211.English Original: The headdress is also very simple compared to the rest of her dress.

W4393303675_s1213.English Original: My personal reaction to Bianca's headdress indicates a dramatic shift in what is considered/ had been considered "fashionable" in fashion history and culture.

W4393303675_s1223.English Original: That portrait has more obvert iconography indicative of Bianca's status and position.

W4393303675_s1224.English Original: Furthermore, that portrait had more of an emphasis on the rest of her body (bust, stomach/ womb, arms, etc), possibly an earlier attempt at this portrait.

The differences between these two portraits hint at a shifting idea of how the sitter wanted or needed

 to be portrayed.

W4393303675_s1226.English Original: This portrait specifically hints more to the viewer's own possible preferences as she hinds her true age, health, and any indication or relation to her lack of children.

W4393303675_s1242.English Original:
Interpretation

 1. Review the material that you have recorded in your observation and reflection on artwork.

W4393303675_s1244.English Original: The amount of overt symbols of rank and wealth.

W4393303675_s1245.English Original: I found this very interesting as it contrasts to other portraits of different women from the same period.

W4393303675_s1246.English Original: The volume of the garments and accessories she wears are defiantly over sized in a blatant manner.

W4393303675_s1247.English Original: Does this work provoke n emotive reaction, connect to your background or interests, or otherwise inspire a research question or questions?

W4393303675_s1248.English Original: This work makes you curious as to why Bianca's identity conveyed through dress is so "loud".

W4393303675_s1249.English Original: What does the work have to say about the artist and the visual traditions of the period in which it was made?

W4393303675_s1250.English Original: The work says that in the Northern Renaissance artistic tradition the emphasis is on the subject of the painting, and all artistic effort is place on that.

W4393303675_s1251.English Original: Thus the background elements are depicted as an afterthought.

W4393303675_s1252.English Original: What does the depiction of fashion in the artwork say about the culture of the period?

W4393303675_s1253.English Original: The depiction of fashion in this work shows that it had emnorumous meaning in European culture tied to numerous aspects about identity (class, gender, wealth, motherhood, etc).

W4393303675_s1254.English Original: Consider the artwork and the fashions depicted therein in relation to a conceptual framework or lens of interpretation that is linked to your research focus.

W4393303675_s1255.English Original: Identify that framework here and briefly consider one or more key texts related to that theory.

W4393303675_s1256.English Original: The suggested frames of references include, but not limited to: status, modernity, ideals of beauty, identity, including gender, sexuality, or ethnicity, politics of representation, and globalization.

W4393303675_s1257.English Original: a. Bianca Maria Sforza was born in April 1472 to the Duke of Milan, Galeazzo Maria Sforza and Bona of Savoy.

W4393303675_s1258.English Original: Following her father's 1476 assassination, the Milanese dukedom fell to her uncle Ludovico, who took on arranging Bianca's future marriages.

W4393303675_s1259.English Original: In 1493, after her first husband had died in 1482, Bianca Maria Sforza married the Holy Roman Emperor Maximilian of the Habsburgs.

W4393303675_s1260.English Original: While Bianca brought with her an exceptionally large dowry and ties to the Milanese dukedom, their marriage was not a "successful" one.

W4393303675_s1261.English Original: By the time of this portrait was painted it was between one and five years before Bianca's premature death (suspected to have been caused by consumption), and Bianca was still, and would remain childless (Rill, 1968).

W4393303675_s1262.English Original: This knowledge appears to affirm certain rationale behind the specific dress identity Bianca aimed to create.

W4393303675_s1263.English Original: It would be advantageous for the childless empress to depict herself in an abundance of jewels and the finest gowns, as a reminder to those at court of her position.

W4393303675_s1264.English Original: Despite her and her husband's distant relationship Bianca still aimed to convey a untied identity to him, as evidenced in his initial appearing on her collar below a crown.

W4393303675_s1265.English Original:
It is also possible that Bianca found solace in jewels, gowns, and the finer things in life

to distract from her distant marriage and feuding family (at the time her uncle, now duke of Milan and her husband were not on good terms).

W4393303675_s1266.English Original: Having in previous years utilized her position to provide aid to Sforza troops against the French, Bianca was notably not a fan of her uncle Ludovico (Rill, 1968).

W4393303675_s1267.English Original: The fact that she is depicted with her hand placed near her stomach could also be indicative of the hope she still had to produce an heir, or a child at all.

W4393303675_s1268.English Original: Sadly, she died in December 1510 childless.
